thread.title: New luxury cruise: New York to Archangel, Russia and back
thread.title_full: New luxury cruise: New York to Archangel, Russia and back

author: USA TODAY
title: New luxury cruise: New York to Archangel, Russia and back
text:
New luxury cruise: New York to Archangel, Russia and back The 89-night voyage on Regent's Seven Seas Navigator will include more than 60 port calls. Post to Facebook New luxury cruise: New York to Archangel, Russia and back The 89-night voyage on Regent's Seven Seas Navigator will include more than 60 port calls.  //usat.ly/2m3Kqqw   Join the Nation's Conversation To   New luxury cruise: New York to Archangel, Russia and back Gene Sloan , USA TODAY 7:47 a.m. ET Feb. 21, 2017 Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Luxury line Regent's 490-passenger Seven Seas Navigator underwent a massive makeover in dry dock during the spring of 2016. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Among the public spaces that are completely new on Seven Seas Navigator is the Library. Regent Seven Seas Cruises The Compass Rose restaurant on Regent's Seven Seas Navigator was completely revamped in a recent makeover. Regent Seven Seas Cruises Changes in the Compass Rose dining room included the addition of new plates by Versace. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Compass Rose dining room on the Seven Seas Navigator now has a new layout. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Seven Seas Navigator's casino featuers all-new chairs, among changes. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A revamped Concierge Suite on the Seven Seas Navigator. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Top suites on the Seven Seas Navigator feature Hermes toiletries. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay The Seven Seas Navigator docked in Venice, Italy. (Photo: Gene Sloan, USA TODAY) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Want to travel to Russia from the United States without getting on an airplane? It'll be doable in 2018. 
Luxury line Regent has announced plans for an epic, 89-night voyage from New York to Russia and back that will include stops in the far-north Russian cities of Murmansk and Archangel. 
The Grand Arctic Splendors voyage, as it's being called, will take place on Regent's recently renovated Seven Seas Navigator — one of the world's most luxurious cruise ships. 
The trip will kick off June 21, 2018 with a transit up the East Coast to Canada. From there, Navigator will sail northeastward across the Atlantic Ocean to Greenland and Iceland before making nearly a dozen stops in Scotland, England, Ireland and Wales. Stops in Belgium and The Netherlands also are on the schedule before the vessel enters the Baltic Sea for visits to Sweden, Finland and its first port in Russia, St. Petersburg. First look: The mind-blowing suites on Regent's new cruise ship 
After St. Petersburg, Navigator will make several more stops in the Baltic region before heading northward along the coast of Norway to the Arctic Circle and the White Sea. It'll then stop at Murmansk and Archangel — two of Russia's northernmost cities and destinations rarely visited by cruise ships from major lines. 
Navigator will return to New York via a more southerly route across the Atlantic that includes stops at Portugal's Madeira Island, the Azores and Bermuda. It'll arrive back in the Big Apple on Sept. 18, 2018. 
Fares for the voyage start at $39,999 per person. 
In sailing from New York to Murmansk and Archangel, Navigator will be following in the wake of the U.S.-led Arctic convoys of World War II, which delivered much-needed supplies to the Soviet Union. More than 1,000 merchant ships escorted by U.S., British and Canadian naval ships took part in the convoys. The convoys put the two ports on the map in the West. 
Regent also has revealed that Navigator will sail an epic, 131-night world cruise in early 2019 that features calls at 62 unique ports. The trip will include stops in the Hawaii Islands, French Polynesia, Australia, Asia and the Mediterranean. Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Billed as the most luxurious cruise ship ever, the 750-passenger Seven Seas Explorer will be christened on July 13, 2016 by Princess Charlene of Monaco. Filippo Vinardi Explorer is the first new ship for luxury line Regent Seven Seas Cruises in more than a decade. It was built at a cost of $450 million -- more per berth than any other cruise vessel afloat. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Explorer boasts an expansive, teak-lined Pool Deck that revolves around a single, rectangular pool filled with salt water. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Explorer's pool is lined with comfortable lounge chairs topped daily with plush white covers. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Attendants place clean towels at every chair. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Located on Deck 11, the pool is flanked by two heated whirlpools. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Circular lounge chairs for two with retractable covers are array around Deck 12 above the main pool. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Located in a corner of the pool area is the Pool Bar, which is bustling on sea days. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Just behind the main pool is the Pool Grill, which serves grilled-to-order burgers, seafood, sandwiches and fresh salads. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Pool Grill has seating for up to 158 passengers at a time and is open for extended hours throughout the day. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Just off the main pool area on Deck 11 is a comfortable lounge area that is covered from the elements. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY One deck up from the main pool, on Deck 12, is a Sports Deck that is ringed with a jogging track and features a netted area for driving golf balls. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Sports Deck on Deck 12 also features an 18-hole putting green that wraps around a paddle tennis court. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The paddle tennis court also can be used for pickelball. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A focal point of Explorer's interior is the nine-deck-high Atrium, which features elegant twin staircases that rise from Deck 4 to Deck 5. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Among the opulent touches on Seven Seas Explorer are intricate, in-laid marble floors such as this one at the base of the Atrium on Deck 4. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Just behind the Atrium staircase on Deck 4 is a marble-lined hallway that brings passengers to Compass Rose, the ship's main restaurant. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Compass Rose offers European-inspired Continental dishes in an elegant setting dominated by light shades of blue, white, gold and silver. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Among upscale touches in Compass Rose, chargers and bread plates are by Versace. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY With a capacity for 386 people, Compass Rose is by far the biggest of Explorer's restaurants. It's open for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY An elaborate, hand-blown Murano glass ceiling fixture serves as a focal point in Compass Rose. The room also is outfitted with rich woods contrasted by light marble stones and mother of pearl. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A closeup of the glasswork above the central tables of Compass Rose. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Sunburst-shaped, hand-blown chandeliers also are spread around Compass Rose. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Explorer offers three main lounges, the biggest of which is the comfortable Meridian Lounge on Deck 5. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Meridian Lounge boasts one of the most expansive bars on Explorer and is a hub for pre-dinner drinks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Meridian Lounge also has one of the largest dance floor on Explorer and a stage for live musical performances. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Name a liquor and you'll probably find it at the Meridian Lounge. As on all Regent ships, the cost of both alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks are included in the fare. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Just across from the Meridian Lounge on Deck 5 is The Cafe, a coffee bar serving made-to-order lattes and other espresso drinks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Seating areas with comfortable chairs are at the center of The Cafe's design. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Cafe has a self-service snack area offering pastries, gourmet sandwiches and homemade cookies throughout the day. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY In addition to barista-made coffee, The Cafe has a self-serve coffee machine tucked into a corner. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Cuisine is a big focus on Explorer, which has more restaurants than any other Regent ship. Among them is Chartreuse, which serves classic French fare with a modern twist. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A new concept for Regent, Chartreuse evokes a chic Parisian restaurant. The dinner menu is a creative mix of classic and contemporary flavors with main courses including seared scallops with chorizo, butternut squash spaghetti and Champagne sauce, and roasted milk-fed veal fillet with raspberry and rhubarb marmalade accompanied by sauteed Swiss chard. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A small bar area at the entrance of Chartreuse is a cozy spot for pre-dinner drinks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY With a capacity for 108 people, Charteuse features a mix of traditional tabletop seating and cozy banquet seating. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Tables for two line one of the walls of Chartreuse. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Explorer also is home to an updated version of Regent's signature steakhouse, Prime 7. It can be found on Deck 10 . Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Reservations are required for Prime 7, which has a capacity for 108 people. As with all the restaurants on Explorer, there is no extra charge to dine. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Lined with rich blue ultrasuede walls and featuring luscious, gray leather chairs, Prime 7 offers a range of prime cut steaks and seafood. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A small bar at the entrance to Prime 7 offers drinks before dinner. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A hallmark of Seven Seas Explorer is its extensive art collection, which was hand-picked by Frank Del Rio, the CEO of Regent's parent company. Here, a Marc Chagall print that hangs in the bar at the Prime 7 steakhouse. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Another new-for-Regent restaurant on Explorer is Pacific Rim, which serves pan-Asian dishes. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Pacific Rim offers such fish dishes as miso black cod wrapped in hoba leaf with pickled daikon. Main course meat dishes include Chinese barbecue pork ribs and Thai green chicken curry. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Chopsticks are de rigueur in Pacific Rim, which has Asian-inspired china and other tabletop touches. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY As at Prime 7, reservations are required to dine at Pacific Rim, which seats just 86 people. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The spare-no-expense decor of Seven Seas Explorer includes a massive, cast-bronze prayer wheel at the entrance to Pacific Rim that cost $500,000. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Casino fans aren't left out on Explorer, which features a small casino on Deck 4 just off the Atrium. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Open when the ship is at sea, Explorer's casino has more than a dozen slot machines as well as six table games. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Explorer's casino has a simple name: The Casino. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Located just off the Atrium on Deck 4, the Explorer Lounge is cozy space for a pre-dinner cocktail or nightcap. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The cozy bar at the Explorer Lounge opens in the evening. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A comfortable nook at the Explorer Lounge, which offers live music nightly. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The stage in the Explorer Lounge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Located at the top of the ship on Deck 11, the Observation Lounge offers panoramic views of the sea. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Floor-to-ceiling windows line the front of the Observation Lounge, offering lounge-goers stunning views over the bow of the ship. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Observation Lounge offers several cozy seating nooks with views of the sea. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A neon-infused corridor on Deck 11 leads to the Observation Lounge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Located on Deck 11, La Veranda is Explorer's casual buffet eatery. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY La Veranda has a spacious buffet area where dishes are in some cases cooked-to-order. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY During breakfast, La Veranda serves made-to-order omelettes, cereals, fruit, pastries and more. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Home-made pastries on display for breakfast at La Veranda. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY La Veranda offers outdoor seating overlooking the back of the ship. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A hand-washing station at the entrance to La Veranda. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Explorer offers a well-stocked library that also serves as a comfortable retreat. Located on Deck 11, it's called, simply enough, The Library. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY A faux fireplace surrounded by large leather chairs is among the charms of The Library. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Also on Deck 11 of Explorer is the Connoisseur Club, a smokers lounge that is open 24 hours a day. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY The Connoisseur Club features fine cigars and spirits such as Scotch whisky and Cognac. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY
